This introductory lecture and laboratory course emphasizes mechanistic approaches to the understanding of human biology. Topics covered include molecular structure, cellular biology, DNA replication and repair, genomics, and population genetics. This course is comparable to Biology 101, but places greater emphasis on molecular mechanisms and experimental approaches. This course fulfills the Living World sector requirement.

While students liked the comprehensive nature of the course, some wished it had gone more in depth on certain topics while sticking to the basics of others that, instead, were closely focused on. One student described the course as a “competitive version of AP Biology,” and another student added that the class was “enjoyable, if stressful.” Lectures were recorded and made available after class, which students found helpful.

Students described Professor Goulian as “articulate” and “confident.” Additionally, several students noted the helpfulness of his presentations, remarking that Goulian presented “clear, concise, and organized lectures.”  

Students thought the course was challenging and many complained about the harsh grading system. It is recommended that students taking this course have a strong background in high school biology and chemistry or be taking CHEM 001 or 101 concurrently.
